lines.text: 45 a few days ago when you left me. What time is it now? Check both watches.
37. I don't.
, I'd like nothing better in the world, but right now I'm sort of... I... I... I'm... tied...
All right, I'm gonna lay my cards on the table. Michael, tell me the truth. Are you with someone?

[showing a photo of a woman]
No. No, I'm chasing her. My dream girl.
Can't be helped. Can't be helped, can it? I apologize to you Michael. I'm truly sorry.
No, no, no. I'm only kidding about her. I'm only doing this for an acquaintance of a friend of mine. I promised to look her up and see about her.
Do you have to see about her tonight?
It doesn't look as though I can tonight.

[leaning in]
Darling! Let's explore Triste together!

I'm with those people over there. They're much duller than you are. But they got far better manners so I have to lie like the dickens. Especially that one guy! He's the captain. He thinks he is a mate of mine. You know the kind. So I have to be nice to him. Darling, can you wait two minutes?
Yup.
Well... I hardly can. I'm going to, darling.
[Joan leans in and passionately kisses Mike. Her cleavage shows]
[scene changes to a waiter looking through some curtains at Joan and Mike. He has an astonished expression, and as he brushes his hair back with his hand his toupee falls back]

[to Janine]
Well, he left in a hurry. It turned out he had an appointment to get killed. That's right, his timing was a little off. You'll be sorry to hear the car got him and not me.
You're making a great mistake Mr. Kells. Sam was my friend.

[to Janine about Sam's watch]
Where did they get this? Did they take it off Sam's body? Was it part of your pay?

[to Mike]
He loved you as only some brothers love.

[about Janine]
She's an appealing dish no doubt. Most bad women are. One way or another, that's why they can be so successfully bad.

[about bugging Janine's apartment]
I want to hear every word she says. I want to hear it when she reads.

[about Joan]
No. If I'm in this, it's my own business. But she's a woman. It's lucky for her she's sore at me. I stood her up last night.
A thing like that just wets her appetite. She'll meet you at one o'clock at the Nationale.
Don't you stop at nothing?
She's an American isn't she? Let her do something for her country.
You started by arousing the mother instinct in me, and now you got the whole works worked up. And you got something stirred up.

[about Mike seeing Joan]
That puts it right in the line of duty. Unnh! Some duty!

[to Mike]
Take it careful brother. You bruise easy.

[to Janine]
Oh no, no, no! I've been to your apartment. I don't like what happens there. Like getting slugged.
You're out of your mind going up there! You got a gun?
Ya.
A flashlight?
No.

[to Joan]
Go home. Take off your spurs and go to bed.
No questions please. I'm standing on the 5th amendment.

[upon seeing Joan]
The widow lady! Live and learn.
If it isn't the cavalry.

[to Mike]
Well, the next time you're near Richmond, Indiana there's a little drug store there. It's practically the whole town. Well, drop in and tell them that the last time you saw me... the little girl is doing great. Just great.

[to Mike]
So... as long you understand that if you do make it necessary, I will violate protocol with personal satisfaction.
[after escaping from a train and tumbling down a steep hillside, Mike and Janine come to rest next to each other]
You know something? This is the first time I really looked at you. Really looked at you, just as a girl.
[last lines]
And so it is.
